did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: This collection is a family archive documenting all of the related branches of the family of Herbert Dimock Pollard. The collection includes photographs, correspondence, scrapbooks, obituaries, poetry, account books and genealogies.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This collection came to CHS from the estate of Evelyn D. Pollard. Her will specified that CHS was to get any papers and photographs related to her father's side of the family which includes Pollard, Dimock, Gardiner, Brigham, Richardson, Gurley, Main and other families of Coventry, CT and nearby towns, as well as pictures of the Brigham Tavern, Wright's Mill, Hale Homestead, scrapbooks of clippings, and genealogy. Papers and photographs related to her mother's Wilbur side of the family from Griswold, CT were to go to other distant family members. However the executors of the estate were unable to find the named family members and the Probate Court decided that CHS would get all of the family archive. CHS deaccessioned most of the Wilbur family papers and photographs, including a scrapbook of clippings, autograph books, and those pictures taken by Edith Wilbur Pollard's brother, Ralph Wilbur, who was a professional photographer, to the Griswold Historical Society. Of special interest were photographs of the Glasgo Yarn Mill and village of which the Wilbur's father James was superintendent, and which are all gone today. CHS deaccessioned some items to the Windham Historical Society, including a scrap book of clippings and photographs of the 1938 hurricane and the family's home at 230 Church St. in Willimantic, CT.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Evelyn Dimock Pollard was born February 5, 1915 in the house known today as the Brigham Tavern on the Boston Turnpike in Coventry, CT. Six generations of her family lived in that house and until about 1850 kept the Tavern there, until her father and mother Herbert D. and Edith (Wilbur) Pollard moved their branch of the family to 230 Church St. in Willimantic, CT where Evelyn lived for the rest of her life. She was a graduate of the Willimantic Normal School and Boston University and taught in the Weathersfield, CT school system for 47 years. She spent some of her retirement years working on the family genealogy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: This collection is a family archive from all of the related branches of the family of Herbert Dimock Pollard, including photographs of paintings (possibly by Erastus Salisbury Field) of Roderick, and Sophia Dimock; photographs of Lewis Addison and Celinda Dimock, William Henry, Sophia, Carlton, and Evelyn Pollard, siblings, cousins and friends; tintypes of Lewis Addison Dimock; photographs of the Brigham Tavern, Great falls of the Skungamaug River, Nathan Hale Homestead and Monument, and the hurricane of 1938; correspondence 1830-50; scrapbooks of clippings that include obituaries, wedding announcements and stories documenting local and family stories and tragedies such as fires, drownings, blizzards and train wrecks; poetry; account books that include evidence of silk skeining; Gold Mining and Land Co. stock certificates; probate documents; genealogy and family history on the Dimock, Wilbur, Robbins, Richardson and Talmadge sides of the family including copies of vital records and National Archives Veterans pension applications, D.A.R. applications, correspondence with other genealogists and related clippings, cemetery lists and manuscript copy of a Dimock genealogy by Alan R. Dimock, M.D. and The Dimocks of Gurleyville, CT by Constance L. Dimock; a poster from the auction that took place when the Brigham Tavern was sold out of the family; programs, tickets and posters from local events including a Concert program of Sacred Music performed at Coventry, CT, 1825, and a poster and ticket for a 1934 production of The Eccentric Cosmopolite by Charles C. Sellers about Itinerant Preacher Lorenzo Dow (native of Coventry, CT); correspondence with George Dudley Seymour confirming George Washington's 1789 stop at the Brigham Tavern, and his interest in the table that Washington reportedly sat at (now in the Nathan Hale Homestead).
